Whitbread has this morning announced the result of its tender offer, with £2bn to be returned to shareholders via the purchase of 40.3m shares at a strike price of £49.72. The tender offer was oversubscribed. The strike price represents the average variable average weighted price plus an amount equal to 2% of the average VWAP.
Tender offers will be accepted as follows: (i) all ordinary shares tendered at a price below the strike price or tendered as a strike price tender will be accepted and purchased in full; (ii) ordinary shares validly tendered at the strike price of average VWAP +2% will be scaled down so the total cost of the shares repurchased does not exceed £2bn. This means that 66.8% of shares validly tendered at this price will be accepted and purchased; (iii) all ordinary shares tendered at a higher purchase price than the strike price (being average VWAP +3% and average VWAP +4%) will be rejected and will not be purchased in the tender offer. The group completed a £482m share buyback earlier this year and following this completion of the tender offer, which will result in £2bn shares being repurchased, Whitbread will have returned a total of £2.5bn to shareholders. The statement notes that the company is not planning on any further returns of capital.
Given our concerns around the UK macro backdrop, soft trading in Regional UK YTD (Q120 RevPAR: -6.4%), and lack of visibility on forward trading around short lead corporate travel (c.25% of bookings) we believe risk to Whitbread numbers remains to the downside. We previously highlighted that the tender offer was providing a valuation support. However, following the completion of this capital return, and confirmation there will be no further return, we believe that at c.23x FY20 P/E and 19x FY21 P/E valuation looks high given the weak trading outlook.

BE11:23am

We upgrade to OW. We believe the negative share price reaction to the marketing announcement earlier this year may have provoked a re-think internally around the need to crystallize value. In One step forward, two steps back, 07/03/19, we highlighted that we saw an upside case of €48 and could turn more positive if we believed that ‘value would now be crystallized which could come from 1) a sustained period with no more self-inflicted downgrades/surprises and 2) a simplification of the business including stake and asset sales with accompanying cash returns’. We believe the group may now finally be on this course with for example the recent Orbis sale announcement and subsequent open approach to cash returns to shareholders representing encouraging signs. We increase our PT to €46 mostly coming from: 1) peer re-rating (1-turn in last 3 months); 2) a narrower discount to IHG, reflecting greater confidence in value-creation and improving Services PMIs. Our upside case, which reflects full value crystallization (and 40% of mkt cap returned as cash), increases to €54 (+38% upside potential) mainly on the peer re-rating. This does not reflect a potential takeout (noting recent speculation from Betaville via Bloomberg) where we see a blue sky mid-point of €60 (+53% upside). Accor is now our preferred hotel pick and IHG remains our least preferred.

Tom Dalgleish @Cloudy, more QA in those places would be a start
BE11:24am

Here's more on the bid angle .....

11:24 am
BE11:24am

As we discussed in the previous section looking at the upside case, we see substantial upside potential for Accor if the assets were to be disposed and cash returned to shareholders. The additional benefit of such an exercise would be that it would leave Accor as a ‘pure-play’ asset-light operator and one which we believe could be attractive to US peers for the following reasons: 1) Accor’s dominance in Europe/Brazil and parts of Asia; 2) brand strengths especially Ibis, Novotel, Fairmont, Raffles; 3) synergy potential. In 2016, US peer Marriott acquired Starwood. Synergies of c$250m were extracted in this deal (c25% of combined SG&A) resulting in an effective post synergy acquisition price of c10.5-11x 2016E EV/EBITDA. The stock currently trades at 15.5x 19E EV/EBITDA. And that has since been considered a successful deal with an arguably ‘cheap’ effective deal.

Our Blue Sky takeout scenario valuation for Accor builds on the scenario in our upside case and then assumes a hypothetical take-out value of 11-12x based on €250m synergies (34% of current EBITDA). This would represent a pre-synergy takeout multiple of 15-16x 20E EV/EBITDA – a 1-turn premium to US peers (average of IHG, Marriott, Choice and Hilton – see Figure 11). We arrive at a range of €57-€63 (mid-point €60).

BE11:28am

TV networks in Europe have years of investment in OTT platforms ahead of them, viewing declines are accelerating, and, in the near term, TV ad markets are under growing pressure. Industry consolidation is unlikely to rescue them from intensifying structural and cyclical headwinds. Still significant earnings risk in European TV: We reiterate our negative view on the European TV industry and lower targets across the group. Despite weak stock price performances over the last year, we see fair value on average 25% below current levels. Viewing of linear networks is declining at an accelerating pace, and, with cyclical pressures also building, we lower our European TV advertising forecasts for 2020 – we now expect every market to decline vs a weak 2019. We see this driving another leg of negative earnings revisions, with the highest risk to consensus EPS at ProSiebenSat.1 (Underweight, PT €10). Sector looks like a value trap: Investors point out to us that on consensus forecasts, European TV screens well for value. We disagree. We highlight (i) linear TV viewing declines are getting worse, with consumption down 5% in the first five months of 2019, against weak comparables; (ii) these trends are almost certainly driven by rising SVOD penetration, where Netflix penetration now averages 23% in the big six territories and is growing at 5% pa, according to Ampere Analysis data. (iii) Viewing declines, driven by rising SVOD penetration, are likely to continue to drive the now well-established shift out of TV advertising in Europe in the near term. (iv) On top of the structural headwinds, a cyclical slowdown in Europe is gathering pace: household consumption growth and corporate profit growth are both declining, providing an inauspicious backdrop for advertising trends in the next 12-18 months. And (v) consensus forecasts do not appear to have factored in these risks: our new 2020 EPS forecasts are 4-20% below consensus, which makes the 2020 P/E look too high at 10.4x (consensus 7.8x) and the 2020 dividend yield of 4.8% (consensus 6.7%) look far from compelling.Is further consolidation likely? Mediaset's acquisition of a stake in ProSiebenSat.1 and its merger proposal for Mediaset España have raised investor expectations that the Italian company may lead further consolidation in the industry.

BE11:29am

We do not subscribe to this view, and highlight that (i) synergies would likely be limited, given European programming is not fungible and represents ~60% of costs, and given we see limited evidence that advertisers will buy TV ad inventory on a pan-European basis; (ii) Mediaset has indicated it does not plan to pay a premium for control, suggesting limited scope to secure the votes of controlling or institutional shareholders; and (iii) industry trends are perhaps "not bad enough" to persuade shareholders or management teams to abandon existing strategies. TV networks have to invest in OTT platforms: Ultimately, regardless of corporate structure, we believe the most important issue for investors in the next 2-3 years is that European TV networks will have to invest in their own Hulu-style OTT platforms. Without this investment, the terminal value of their traditional TV businesses will continue to decline, in our view.

BE11:29am

BE11:35am

Abcam expects to report FY19 total revenues of £259.9m, boosted by a c.£5m FX benefit, growing 9.2% at CER (11.4% reported). This missed the company's guidance of 10% growth at CER, due to continued weakness in Japan and a decline in the custom project side of Abcam Inside. Management still expect adj. EBITDA margins to be in line with guidance of 35%. We take the opportunity to marginally reduce our FY20-22 catalogue revenue growth forecasts, to be inline with the current run-rate. Gavin Wood, CFO, has also announced his intention to step down for personal reasons, this will take place within the next 12 months to facilitate a smooth transition. We fundamentally like Abcam's business model as it generates a dependable, growing, earnings stream and we can therefore see why it trades at a premium to its peers. However, with the Abcam Inside program still struggling to gain meaningful traction and a slowing of the catalogue growth rate, due to the law of larger numbers ... we struggle to take a more positive view on the stock and thus continue to see fair value at 1,100p, which would place it on 34.8x FY20 PE.

BE11:37am

Geographically Abcam has indicated growth in China of over 20%, this compares to 22.4% in H1 and 26% FY 2018. Although this remains an impressive growth rate the continuing decline indicates Abcam’s increasing maturity in the region. Peer performance suggests trading in the US in the period would have been strong as improved NIH funding drives science spending, this supports the in line catalogue growth.

BE11:37am

These results, coming despite the downgrades to consensus throughout the year, highlight our underlying concerns with Abcam. Core catalogue grew at 9.8% (10.5% H1 2019) with growth of 22% from recombinant antibodies (22.08% FY 2018) and 22% from immunoassays, a good performance benefitting from the annualization of the Spring Bioscience acquisition (January 2018). Slightly disappointingly Customer engagement has fallen from 64% FY 2018 to 59% FY 2019, though remains within the KPI band of 57-67%; a further fall would be concerning.

Excel Developer though that article from 2015
11:38 am
BE11:38am

FY results are expected on the 9th September, to be followed by a Capital Markets Day on 14th November. Each of these events is expected to give detail on the new five year plan to 2023/24 for Abcam. The last five years saw both the introduction of a new ERP system and move to a new building with the expectation that margins would rise following the completion of these projects. Initial indications from the statement are that the next five years will involve a further “program of internally funded investments” suggesting to us that margins are unlikely to climb from current levels in the near term, contrary to consensus which indicates an increase from FY 2019.
 A bcam trading is 26.6x EBITDA and 39.3x PE FY 2020 and in our view remains over valued compared to its peer group, particularly since we expect the growth rate to be increasingly difficult to maintain and further pressure on consensus. We maintain our SELL recommendation.

Goodbody says this:

BE11:45am

Sky News reported on Sunday that MTRO “is this weekend applying the finishing touches to a £500m deal to offload a mortgage portfolio” to Cerberus (see: https://news.sky.c...oan-deal-11767909). MTRO subsequently published a response to the press speculation this morning confirming that discussions regarding the potential sale of a loan portfolio are taking place. However, the release provides no further clarity around the timing of the potential sale. The loans concerned are understood to constitute loans to customers who do not have current accounts with MTRO, meaning no loss of ‘strategic value’ as it were. We have previously opined, on multiple occasions, that we believed that management would pursue further asset sales – likely to be the assets that were the subject of RWA misstatements (given the RWA density reduction benefit attached to selling those assets). As our 28th May 2019 research report (available at the link below) noted: “…management has noted that asset sales / securitisations represent optional courses of action – probably because it does not want to appear like a forced seller, which would seem sensible. However, the numbers are clear in our view - if MTRO does not raise more CET1 capital it will need to sell assets. The assets that were subject to the RWA misstatements would seem ripe for plucking in this respect given the high attached RWA intensity. Assuming it could sell these assets at their face value of c.£1.64bn, we compute that MTRO would generate an uplift in its CET1 capital ratio of c.240bps (pre-fees). However, this will come at the expense of run rate profitability (our modelling indicates a c.£30m hit to net income in such a scenario) – though we appreciate that capital is a priority to profitability at the current juncture.”. The pro-forma CET1 capital impact based on a £500m loan sale is c.73bps (pre-fees) based on our estimates, which assume that MTRO could sell the assets at face value. We remain cautious in relation to the longer-term profitability headwinds arising from disposals. We also wonder whether MTRO has been under pressure to sell assets to slim down the size of its Balance Sheet – for example, if funding challenges became more pronounced in May, which we suspect they did. Many questions and any excitement that drives share price gains tomorrow in response to this news article should be seen as an opportunity to build on a short position.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

MOST's FX folks say:

FATDAZ BBC suggesting that JH may be made chancellor as sop to those that didn't vote for BoJo
BE12:00pm

We expect the new prime minister to demand a deal without an Irish backstop, which the EU will not agree to. With gridlock in parliament, we think resolving Brexit will require a political process, leading to further delay, and a more binary outcome. A new PM on July 24: The Conservative leadership contest is nearly done. The ballot will close on July 22. The 1922 Committee will declare the winner on July 23, and he is set to become prime minister in the course of July 24. This implies that the new prime minister will be in place for only one sitting day of the Commons before it rises for recess on July 25. With the new prime minister in post, the Brexit process – on pause since late May – is set to restart.Advantage Johnson: Since the start of the contest, Mr. Johnson has been the frontrunner, with more support among MPs and in polls of Conservative party members. According to YouGov, his margin of victory could be as large as 48pp. A no-deal government... However, both candidates are committed to a deal without the Irish backstop, while the EU has said there is no deal without the Irish backstop. Unless the EU backs down on the backstop – and we are sceptical that it will – this position will end up being a policy of leaving the EU without a deal. In addition to the Irish backstop issue, Mr. Johnson has said he wants the right to withhold payment of the UK's outstanding obligations ('Brexit bill'), which the EU also sees as a condition for a deal, and he has said he is committed to leaving the EU on the October 31 deadline. ...plus a parliament opposed to no deal = early elections? The Commons has not voted for any solution, but has voted heavily against a no-deal outcome. Meanwhile, the government's majority is down to four, and a number of Conservative MPs have committed to opposing a no-deal outcome. So if the UK is heading for the default no-deal outcome, we think that parliament is likely to act to prevent such an outcome. We see little chance of a resolution without a new political process – probably elections, and probably at the end of the year. Easier fiscal policy: Through the campaign, both candidates have announced a range of expansionary fiscal measures, amounting from 1% of GDP (Johnson) to 1.7% of GDP (Hunt). With the Labour party also favouring easier fiscal policy – e.g., the 2017 manifesto promised 1.2% of GDP in additional public investment – both main parties are now seemingly committed to easier fiscal policy. FX views: Markets are positioned short GBP and should remain this way throughout the period of uncertainty. In this note we address investor queries with GBP ranges for a variety of outcomes (e.g., no deal, new elections, etc.). GBP implied volatility is elevated over the October 2019-January 2020 period. GBP downside tail hedges are still relatively cheap to play for a move below 1.20 by year-end.
